page.title: 17A55 HOLYWELL BY-PASS
page.content: The main A55(T) road into North Wales carries heavy{freight traffic}from Ireland to Britain and Europe. Since Britain joined the E.E.C. this traffic has greatly increased. During the summer{tourists}travelling by coaches and cars, (many towing caravans), create traffic jams at the Holywell traffic lights as up to 3000 cars per hour pass through. 1985 saw the beginning of construction of the{A55 Holywell By-pass.}Due to be completed by the autumn of 1987 this dual-carriageway follows a southerly route around the town over Halkyn Mountain. Among the obstacles to be overcome are the many disused mine shafts, a legacy of the lead mining. Costing Â£13 million the by-pass forms part of the planned{ Euro-route} linking Ireland to Britain and the continent.
